comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content:
An excellent portrait of a very handsome and demure young couple.  As the (Major) Bishops Bride Limerick would have had potentially unpleasant connections for the young lady.  Another Bishops bride was made notorious in the great Limerick saga "Drunken Thady and the Bishops lady" which may be summed up by the few lines below!  I am sure that this young lady was nothing like the other and I hope that she lived a long and happy life?

Tis true she lived, tis true she died,
tis true she was the bishops bride,
she lived like most ungodly ladies
spending his Reverend Lordships treasure
chasing the worlds evil pleasure.
In love with supper, cards and balls
and luxurious sin in festive halls
where flaming hearts and flaming wine
invite the passions all to dine!

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: I have just Googled Familysearch with no warnings. I use the latest Firefox browser on a Windows computer and also a Firefox Linux Mint netbook. I never use Internet Explorer. Familysearch comes from the Mormon Church in Salt Lake City, Utah. It was the first website to put the 1881 census online for free about 10 years ago. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FamilySearch "2008: The Vatican issued a statement calling the practice known as baptism for the dead 'erroneous' and directing its dioceses to keep parish records from Mormons performing genealogical research." I can only think that the NLI antivirus system is very sensitive. Does the "untrusted connection" alert occur both at work and at home?

comment.author: 69699465@N00
comment._content: Ah, whenever I see these old glass plate photos it brings home to me just how timeless the real elements of photography are - focus, exposure, lighting, pose, all damn near perfect in this despite its age (or maybe because of it - a portrait session would have been a rather more time-consuming process back then). I used to work in a lab in Ennis and we'd often get people bringing in old family heirloom 8x10s for rescanning or restoration, most likely contact prints from large negs like this, and the sheer sharpness and beautiful tonality never ceased to amaze me.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content:
"Major" was and is an unusual rank in Ireland.  The IRA did not use it as they preferred Commandant and the modern Irish Defence Force equivalent rank is the same, Commandant rather than Major. Perhaps some of our military specialists might be able to tell us by the rank markings.  Incidentally in that era rank markings were mostly worn on the cuffs of the uniform tunic and not on the epaulette or collar.  The dullness of these rankings would indicate to me that he was a Sergt. Major, who wore similar uniforms to the commissioned ranks but had red rank markings.
Congratulations Carol on yet another Explore!!!

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: The Irish Defence Forces or Oglaigh na hÉireann were established in October 1924 and the equivalent rank to Major was and remains Commandant.  This portrait was taken in May of that year and during the hiatus between the treaty/civil war and the establishment it may be that Major was a recognised rank.  I doubt it but could not be positive.  I think that his rank markings were for RSM but???

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Orthochromatic film was insensitive to red and could be developed under a red light in the darkroom. It would show red markings as black. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panchromatic The marriage certificate will show how he describes his rank. Come on NLI, find out his full name and buy the certificate.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66105333@N06] www.militaryarchives.ie/useful-information/faq How do I gain access to personnel records of an ancestor or relative who served in the Defence Forces or National Army? Personnel records are currently available to direct next of kin only. In exceptional circumstances, direct next of kin may give permission to a third party researcher to proceed with an enquiry on their behalf. Military Archives requires a signed letter of application for personnel records along with copies of birth cert(s) to establish an applicant’s relationship to personnel of interest. The OIC Military Archives may request a death certificate for the subject and/or a sworn affidavit stating the next of kin relationship. If you are direct next of kin, you should apply to see your ancestors’ records as follows: 2. If the subject left the Defence Forces more than thirty years ago: For officers (i.e. Lieutenants, Captains, Commandants etc.) and for enlisted personnel (i.e. privates, corporals, sergeants etc.) – write directly to OIC Military Archives, as per the contact address.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: In the 1911 census, Walter Bishop (confectioner), his 3 young children and sister-in-law Margret Power were living in Strand Street, Tramore, Waterford www.census.nationalarchives.ie/pages/1911/Waterford/Tramore/Strand_Street/911729/" His wife Bridget Bishop (confectioner) and son Michael Bishop (12) were living in Michael Street, Waterford. www.census.nationalarchives.ie/pages/1911/Waterford/Water... Michael Bishop was born in 1898 or early 1899.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] How interesting that Michael has been struck through on the Household Return (Form A)! comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content:
Email to me from Military Archives
"Thanks for your email. A search of our collections has returned reference to an officer Major Michael Joseph Bishop born 28 October 1898. He enlisted February 1922, commissioned 14 March 1923 and resigned with effect from 16th February 1929. He is listed as having 3 years previous service with the British Army (I.G. - presumably Irish Guards) and 3 years previous service with the IRA, East Waterford Brigade.
Ranks within the Army were not fully standardised in the 1920s. While "Major" is not now a rank in the Defence Forces (Comdt would be the nearest equivalent), there were a small number of officers carrying this rank in the 1920s.
I hope this information is of some assistance.
Regards
Noelle Grothier
Archivist"

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] That information certainly "is of some assistance"!! So that gels with all that you and D.Bishop1 contributed, doesn't it? And now we have an exact date of birth too: 28 October 1898. This is so fantastic! Yet again, all of you are making an old library (121 and a half) very happy... :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 13130682@N02
comment._content:
Ranks within the Army were not fully standardised in the 1920s. While "Major" is not now a rank in the Defence Forces (Comdt would be the nearest equivalent), there were a small number of officers carrying this rank in the 1920s.".......................

The Rank of Major in the British Army and U.S.Army equates to the Rank of Comandant. However the Irish Army Rank of Major existed between Sept 1924 and Sept. 1977 and was between the Ranks of Commandant and Colonel,
 In 1977 The rank  was renamed Lieutenant Colonel,in Order to reduce confusion overseas !

comment.author: 80823778@N05
comment._content:
Hello... great picture and history. 
Her smile is quite serene ...lovely
my friends father whos 94 remembers as a toddler hearing the roads thunder under foot of the black and tans horses. Mount Clanard and his mother grabbing him and his baby brother and rushing to hide in the ditches in the bottom of their garden. he remembers his mothers eye wide, with her hands over both of theirs mouths, pleading for silence.
I know this is not the history you are after but this story is one he speaks of quite alot and has always stayed with me.

comment.author: 77603809@N02
comment._content:
Rank markings were re-arranged on 31 January 1923:[15]

Rank Bars Worn 
Private N/A N/A 
Corporal 1 Green Left Arm 
Sergeant 2 Green Left Arm 
Sergeant Major 3 Green Left Arm 
2nd Lieutenant 1 Blue Shoulder Strap 
Lieutenant 2 Blue Shoulder Strap 
Captain 3 Blue Shoulder Strap 
Commandant 2 Red Shoulder Strap 
Colonel 3 Red Shoulder Strap and Collar 
Major General 2 Red with 1 Gold between Shoulder Strap and Collar 
Lieutenant General 2 Gold Shoulder Strap and Collar 
General 3 Gold Shoulder Strap and Collar 

I don't know if this late entry has any value, but this is what Wikipedia seems to say about INA rank insignia...I've enjoyed reading this wonderful comment thread in any case. My own name harks back to Ulster, actually :)
